docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Presidential organization has abruptly scrapped his radio and television commercials and plans to start an extensive, $225,000 media campaign in New England that seeks to deal with the Chappaquiddic...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Presidential organization has abruptly scrapped his radio and television commercials and plans to start an extensive, $225,000 media campaign in New England that seeks to deal with the Chappaquiddick issue and that attacks President Carter's handling of foreign and domestic problems.
docs.abstract: Kennedy's Presidential campaign scraps previous radio and TV commercials and plans to begin extensive media campaign in New England seeking to deal with Chappaquiddick issue (S)

headline.main: KENNEDY CAMPAIGN ALTERS ADVERTISING; $225,000 New England Drive Will Deal With the Chappaquiddick Issue and Carter Policies Chappaquiddick Issue Internal Debate

docs.snippet: Public television is entering the 1980's with a cascade of brave new words about the future. At a recent "program fair" in San Francisco. Chloe Aaron was only one of several Public Broadcasting Service officials urging stations to rally around the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Public television is entering the 1980's with a cascade of brave new words about the future. At a recent "program fair" in San Francisco. Chloe Aaron was only one of several Public Broadcasting Service officials urging stations to rally around the ideal of quality programming. As senior vice president for programming, Miss Aaron declared that the promise of public television will not keep for another decade.
docs.abstract: Article on strained relations between Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) and independent TV producers over financing of programs and programming content; PBS official Chloe Aaron and independent producer Marc Weiss comment (M)

headline.main: TV VIEW; Public TV and Independents-- Wary Partners

docs.snippet: THE exposure of technicians to potentially dangerous levels of vapors from two cancer-caus-  ing chemicals has resulted in the state's Department of Health beginning to replace the entire air-duct and ventilation system in its five-story laborator...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE exposure of technicians to potentially dangerous levels of vapors from two cancer-caus- ing chemicals has resulted in the state's Department of Health beginning to replace the entire air-duct and ventilation system in its five-story laboratory building in Trenton.
docs.abstract: NJ Health Dept begins to replace air-duct and ventilation systems in its laboratory building, Trenton, after technicians were exposed to potentially dangerous levels of vapors from 2 cancer-causing chemicals, benzene and chloroform, in department's Narcotics-Detection Laboratory; department studies health of 76 people employed in laboratory between its opening in '72 and last Aug, when complaints about fumes were 1st registered; laboratory used chemicals to extract drugs from urine samples (M)
